comments.commentBody:
I said it before and I'll say it again, we need standards for people who wish to participate in Congress and effect laws that not only impact human beings and life in general in this country as well as globally, but impact them for generations to come.
Just as law makers wouldn't tolerate colleagues who aren't toilet trained or are unable to find their home state on a map, they also should not tolerate those who apparently couldn't manage to pass basic high school math and science. Unfortunately, such seems to be the case for a majority of the Republican law makers.
Interestingly, this willful ignorance puts them at odds with their conservative constituents. According to a poll conducted by ClearPath, conservatives DO favor taking measures against global warming. Take a look at the site below where you will find the link to a PDF with very precise questions on how Republican voters feel about global warming and what to do about it. The answers are astonishing.
http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/new-national-poll-shows-strong-r...

Participation In a democracy does not have any knowledge/education requirement, and certainly once elected, you are equal among all other elected representatives, So, you don't need to satisfy any of the other lawmakers minimum standards, or expectations.

Democracy is the people electing one among them. That was the idea at least. What we have is a whole different can of worms.
Richman? I don't think so. Impoverished soul more likely.

Bizzaro Fox News? As opposed to non-bizzaro Fox News?

Paranoia is a tendency on the part of an individual or group toward excessive or irrational suspiciousness and distrustfulness of others. Especially if she's been persecuted mercilessly by Fox News and Senate hearings by Republicans.

Hasn't Scott Walker been governor for several years?

Those blue prairie grasses have been scorched for a while now...

Sayeeshwar.......climate change is already happening.  And if you don't believe climatologists, maybe you should know it is already a given to horticulturists, foresters, botanists, zoologists, geologists, oceanographers, biologists, etc......who factor it into research on planetary life.  They aren't all political about it, and they don't all depend on government funding.  Climate change is just the scientifically accepted model.  Really, the only "skeptics" left are industrialists, politicians and their followers, and you don't think they have more of an agenda?

The mirror (media) mislead her and she compounded her problems with trustworthiness by not discouraging the likes of Wasserman-Schultz.
(innately dishonest,self-centered,spoiled and deplorable) and Donna Brazeil
(blindly ambitious, though previously likeable).
He will charge the feds 3x the cost of repairs.  He already got 27 million for slight damage.

Oh please, Tru.o never left anyone to DIE anywhere, then left office to limit the backlash for that to try and save a presidential run.  If anyone in the military did what she did with classified Intel on civilian emails, they would be in prison ... That's right, fort Leavenworth.  That's fact.  That's not an assumption, why is she not there?  The FBI can't hold her to the USC (US Code... Law in other words), but those same dealings can land servicemen and servicewomen in Prison).  To quote a picture I saw.... "I'd rather be offended by trump than left for dead by clinton."
Because Men can be repugnant. But a woman must be a virgin.
Hmmm. There seem to be an awful lot of men in this picture.
That is exactly what I thought.
Have you considered the possibility that some of the people shown are transgender or multi-gender?
I know a Canadian couple who have cancelled a long-planned trip to view the eclipse, next summer, because they are fearful of coming here, once Trump is in power.
Why would anyone want to travel to a country that elected President Grab Em? I wish I could leave this country for four years.
We always knew Trump wanted to be President for the money he will make.

• TRAVEL TO THE UNITED STATES –...inbound travel will dry up....

"I have no further use for America. I wouldn't go back there if J.C. was President." ~ CHARLIE CHAPLIN, a.k.a. Sir Charles Spencer Chaplin

I am a 71-year-old US citizen until January, when I will become fully Canadian. Though my decision came prior to this election, this last year-and-a-half has totally "radicalized" me. I never felt comfortable, that I 'belonged', in the U.S., even after living in NY for almost 40 years, and I have sworn NEVER to set foot in the U.S. or its territories, especially my native Puerto Rico, again and I won't. I have severed all ties with the U.S except for bourbon, the one good thing that ever came out of there, by accident and violently – like the nation itself, born of fire.

“I'm sorry if you don't like my honesty but, to be fair, I don't like your lies.” ~ ANONYMOUS

Donald Trump's election has cemented it all. He is no anomaly. Trump IS the U.S.A., Burdick and Lederer's 1958 classic "The Ugly American" personified:
"A mysterious change seems to come over Americans when they go to a foreign land. They isolate themselves socially. They live pretentiously. They are loud and ostentatious."

All the ugliness has finally come home to roost in Donald Trump!

To anyone attempting a smug reply to this comment (if published), say what you will. My response is that of Rhet Butler to Scarlet O'Hara at the end of Gone with the Wind, "Frankly, my dear, I don't give a damn."

...right there with you Robert, dual citizen that I am.  just need to claw my way through two years of school and then my mixed-race family and I can make the move permanent.  True North Strong and Free....

As a Canadian living near the border, I've enjoyed visiting many parts of the US. I was in Syracuse just last weekend with a friend and we joked that it might be our last time in the States before we began building our border wall. We were joking because we were confident that the US would elect Mrs. Clinton on Tuesday. Given how things turned out, I'll be giving US visits a pass for the time being. I'm not trying to sound superior, as Canada is not perfect and we certainly have our problems. But as shock turns to sadness, I'm disappointed that nearly half of US voters would elect a man whose campaign relied on lies, slurs and fear mongering to the office of President. The country that I've always thought of as friendly and welcoming doesn't seem that way anymore.

Hello Canada!  Well, I wasn't one of the people who voted for Trump and as you may now see, the majority of us did not vote for him.  I am already reading about violence on college campuses toward minorities and yes, it will make a difference to choose where I travel, being concerned about how I will be treated now as an American.  I've even looked at options on finding property in another country (maybe Canada!) as a safe haven for me and my family should the need arise.  Ontario looks really good right now!

" I am already reading about violence on college campuses toward minorities"

Please enlighten us as to where these incidents are taking place? I've seen none reported in the New York Times or any other news source. I am reading though of people from the Left destroying personal and public property and denying others access to places and calling it "protest".

How many more links do you want?:

http://nymag.com/daily/intelligencer/2016/11/hundreds-of-hate-crimes-rep...

http://www.nytimes.com/2016/11/12/us/reports-of-bias-based-attacks-tick-...

http://thecrimereport.org/2016/11/12/hate-attacks-reported-up-since-trum...

http://people.com/politics/swastika-graffiti-and-build-the-wall-taunts-i...

Geez. WAKE UP TO REALITY!

“We are going to fix our inner cities and rebuild our highways, bridges, tunnels, airports, schools, hospitals,” Mr. Trump said during his victory speech.

That won't be done for a long time, and any airport under construction is one I want to avoid. I had to travel internationally for years after 9/11 and the Bush DHLS regulations on travel to the US resulted in reciprocal red tape from other countries towards American travelers. Throw in retribution for Trump's promised tariff wars and we can alol just plan on going to Disney Land for the next 4 years.

It was hard enough for me personally to explain George Bush to the rest of the world, there is no way to explain Trump. Everyone asks you. Everyone. Since you're a "crass blunt American", they are not delicate about it. The conversation usually starts something like "Are American crazy?"

Maybe this is where the safety pin can be helpful- to let people know that ou are safe to talk with about this.  If they have been paying attention - and they have- they get our pain.  The people I talk with while traveling are generally better informed than many Americans.

it may or may not be a significant number, but there are white people that are no longer interested in travelling to the United States.  I know many of them, and I face one in the mirror every morning.

I think you may be in for a nasty surprise: He doesn't care about you out there in the industrial heartland.

Also, very few people agree with your view of climate change as a "charade". Most people and most scientists agree it's real, and changing faster than anticipated.

I hope to God it's not as simple as you think to trash the Paris Accords, destroy the EPA and crank up Keystone. There may be nothing to stop you - as you so graciously point out - but you'll have to do it quickly because I and many others will do everything in our power to stop you from despoiling the planet.

I

I feel better in just giving up. I'm moving to saner pastures. I could not stand another set of George Bush years headed this time by an orangutan. Danger from the new government on both domestic and foreign policy looms. It really could degenerate like Post Wiemar Germany.
Oh it probably won't and many have pointed out that his reach is limited. But the parallels to the rise of the 3rd Reich are numerous. If a terrorist disaster takes place *or is manufactured* on his watch - look out.
Between "restoring order" and "making America great again" is a lot of ground ripe for totalitarianism and domestic and foreign war.
Smart Germans left Germany early, before things turned into WW2.

OK--where do "we" go? The world is more interconnected now than ever before. The United States is not an island--literally or figuratively. What's happening here is happening almost everywhere--the very concept of democracy is under siege in many countries. And let's not forget that many of those "smart" Germans (and other Europeans who correctly saw the rise of fascism as a danger) often times could not escape their fate since "safe" countries (like the United States) wouldn't accept them because of immigration laws designed to protect against outsiders.

Instead of running away, do something useful. Get involved at the local level. Support progressive candidates. Give a damn about the state of world.

Don't mourn. Organize.

Or crawl into a hole and hope it all blows over.
Several German papers have already made the analogy.  They have pointed out that Germans have seen this happen in the early thirties and they now know exactly where it led to.

When the "climate crazies" ground the airline industry world-wide, which dumps thousands of tons of carbon at 40,000 feet all day, every day, do call. Till then, it's just more self-serving, feel-good bourgeois hypocrisy. And, big surprise, the earth don't care--climate has been changing--and will continue to do so--for more than four billion years--man or not.

Problem is too, too many humans in too many poor economies, and more coming every year.

Hillary got far more votes than Bernie, a few million, and won more states.  By what logic do you assume that someone who was less popular, overall, and got fewer votes than Hillary would have had a better shot? He was popular with the far left for sure, but how would he win the swing states, the blue dog vote? The republicans would simply have had a different line of attack and would have called him a socialist, etc. Don't forget Comey's impact and the fact that Hillary actually won the popular vote. It was a dirty campaign and anything could have happened.

and Elke
Today/tomorrow is Nov.11 ; Remembrance Day here in Canada; Veterans Day in the US. Red poppies are worn on lapels.
Here's my annual SALUTe to all the veterans who fought and died to preserve democracy, with a link to John McCrae's "In Flanders Fields": this poem is taught in ELEM school in Canada, and most can recite it by heart:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/In_Flanders_Fields
We had our two minutes of silence in my French class this morning..
And it's my granddaughter's birthday, too - it was 11 minutes past the 11th hour p.m., so it's listed here as 23:11, but she had all the 11s.  (She's the one who just got married. She's 27 today.)
It was Armistice Day when I was a kid. It will always be Armistice Day for me.

As I said for many months and was routinely censored for saying so:

Trump is right about tariffs, and right about outsourcing to China being bad, and right about calling an illegal illegal not undocumented. (Obama maybe threw Trump the election by his unilateral attempt to grant amnesty to illegals, and the Nytimes did not help by not airing opinions like mine which said so)

Trump is wrong about Obamacare and wrong about lowering taxes.

But none of these issues really matter. China would have but it is passed the horse has bolted. We have succeeded control. The only issue that matters is the enviroment. All paths to the future are calamity.

To roll back the tiny attempts being made will render Trump as it did early days Obama (who did way too little for political expediency) to the dust heap of history.

In a recent report, the IPCC has opined that the Paris accord is insufficient to stop the rise of global temperature by at least 2 degrees Celcius. But many experts in the field, including former IPCC leaders, have stated that the catastrophic effects anticipated if the 2 degree mark is breached will happen even if the current rise to 2 degrees is the reality.

“There is no such thing as a safe rise,” said Bob Watson, who was the chair of the IPCC from 1997 to 2002. “You will see food and water insecurity, human health problems, and sea level rise even with a 2 C rise.”

Given that the climate scientists get funding from the governments to support their raison-d'etre and to carry on with their 'research' work, it is unthinkable that they will bite the hand that feeds them. If they came up with the finding that, as Bob Watson said, there is no safe temperature threshold and what is projected to happen with a breach of 2 degrees rise is also likely to happen to the same extent if that threshold is breached.

It is the group-think among climate scientists who depend on State funding of their research that will suffer if Trump proceeds to cut off funding for this nonsense.

The sky is not falling, people.

@PISonny.......you seem to think climate studies are some oddly disconnected and corruptible niche, when in fact climate models are used daily by scientists in many fields, whether or not they receive government funding.  Monsanto acknowledges climate change.  The Pentagon identifies climate change as a national security threat.  Engineers use models of climate change for stress tests.  Exxon-Mobil's own scientists predicted climate change back in the 70's.  The politically, financially motivated niche you speak of is not climatologists.....it's deniers.  But if you're honest with yourself, you already know that.
Sonny you can deny it all you want.  Doesn't change that it's happening, when it affects you, maybe you'll snap out of your delusion.  Of course, it won't matter what you think at that point either.

And yet the climate models predicted a much faster rise in global temperatures over the past 15-20 years than actually happened, indicating that one or more key aspects of the climate system are not properly represented in those models. Even the modelers admit that current models have no statistical skill in projecting regional temperatures or rainfall, and won't for at least another decade.  Not much of a sound basis for public policy.

Sven, I hope you are kidding.  If not, maybe you will consider reading the book, The Sixth Extinction.  While the climate has changed over this planet's history, natural climate change tends to be slow, incremental.  Species have time to migrate or evolve.  Man-made climate change is so rapid, it is more akin to the cataclysmic events that set off mass extinctions.
